citation.article-title: A numerical classification of the genus Bacillus.

p.s: Description of Bacillus kaustophilus (Prickett, 1928) nom. rev.
Bacillus kaustophilus (kau.sto.ph'il.us. Gr. n. kaustos, heat; Gr, adj. philus loving; M.L. adj. kaustophilus heat loving)
The description is taken from the present and several other studies (Prickett, 1928; Walker & Wolf, 1971; Sharp et al., 1980).

Strains in this species have similar properties to B. stearothermophilus but differ from members of this species by their ability to produce acid from cellobiose, meso-inositol and xylose, to degrade testosterone and to reduce nitrate to gas, and by their relative sensitivity to NaCl and failure to grow anaerobically.

They produce oval to cylindrical spores that distend the sporangium to a greater or less extent, liquefy gelatin, degrade aesculin, arbutin, pullulan and starch (weakly), and grow optimally between 60 and 65Â°C.

The mol% G + C of the DNA of the five strains studied falls within the range 51 to 55 (Tm).
There is evidence that these strains form a distinct DNA homology group (Sharp et al., 1980).
